Graphical abstract Growing plastic waste amounts are drawing attention, while plastic recycling alone cannot solve the current crisis. In this review, recent progress in developing plastic upcycling through electrocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic reactions, alternative solutions to manage plastic waste, is comprehensively introduced. Plastic, renowned for its versatility, durability, and cost-effectiveness, is indispensable in modern society. Nevertheless, the annual production of nearly 400 million tons of plastic, coupled with a recycling rate of only 9%, has led to a monumental environmental crisis. Plastic recycling has emerged as a vital response to this crisis, offering sustainable solutions to mitigate its environmental impact. Among these recycling efforts, plastic upcycling has garnered attention, which elevates discarded plastics into higher-value products. Here, electrocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic treatments stand at the forefront of advanced plastic upcycling. Electrocatalytic or photoelectrocatalytic treatments involve chemical reactions that facilitate electron transfer through the electrode/electrolyte interface, driven by electrical or solar energy, respectively. These methods enable precise control of chemical reactions, harnessing potential, current density, or light to yield valuable chemical products. This review explores recent progress in plastic upcycling through electrocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic pathways, offering promising solutions to the plastic waste crisis and advancing sustainability in the plastics industry. Keywords Plastic upcycling Electrocatalytic reaction Photoelectrocatalytic reaction Value-added product 1 Introduction Plastic has become an essential component of human life due to its remarkable versatility, durability, and cost-effectiveness, with an annual global production of nearly 400 million tons [1,2]. Unfortunately, only about 9% of plastic waste is recycled, leaving the remaining 364 million tons to be landfilled, incinerated, or improperly disposed (Fig. 1 ) [3–5]. Table 1 shows the global production and waste of common plastics in 2019. Clearly, the waste volumes of plastics approximate their production levels, which strongly emphasize the importance of plastic recycling. Most plastic products take centuries to degrade due to their physical and chemical resistance, and they end up in oceans, rivers, and landfills, inflicting severe environmental damage. Annually, millions of tons of plastic end up in the oceans, posing significant threats to marine life and ecosystems [6,7]. Moreover, as plastics break down into microplastics, they infiltrate soil and freshwater systems, and can even enter the food chain, posing serious health risks to humans and animals alike [8–10]. The American Chemistry Council reported that the potential economic impact of plastic recycling technologies in the U.S. will reach up to $10 billion. Moreover, the Association of Plastic Recyclers announced that plastic recycling alone accounts for over 200,000 U.S. jobs and expects that replacing new plastic with recycled plastic can reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 70%. Current plastic recycling technologies can be broadly categorized into two groups: mechanical recycling and chemical recycling (Fig. 1) [11–13]. Mechanical recycling involves collecting, sorting, cleaning, and processing used plastics to create new plastic products. However, this process can lead to the degradation of plastics with each recycling cycle, and not all types of plastics can be effectively recycled mechanically. On the other hand, chemical recycling, also known as advanced recycling or feedstock recycling, involves breaking down plastic waste into its chemical building blocks or converting it into valuable chemicals, fuels, or feedstocks. Chemical recycling can handle a wider variety of plastic types, including those that are challenging to recycle mechanically. However, it is a complex and energy-intensive process that requires careful consideration of environmental and economic factors. Both mechanical and chemical recycling will play vital roles in reducing plastic waste and advancing towards a more circular and sustainable economy. Beyond traditional plastic recycling, plastic upcycling, a process of transforming waste materials into products of higher value or utility, has recently gained increasing attention [14–18]. Unlike recycling, which often results in downcycling (transforming materials into lower-quality products), upcycling aims to convert plastic waste into products of higher value or utility than the original material. Although plastic upcycling techniques are still in their infancy, various techniques have been reported and can be categorized into four distinct types: (1) pyrolysis, (2) photocatalytic conversion, (3) biological conversion, and (4) electrocatalytic conversion [19–24]. Each upcycling technique has pros and cons which hinder commercialization, but all the techniques are crucial for addressing the environmental crisis caused by plastic waste. Among the plastic upcycling techniques, the electrocatalytic method, though less developed than others, holds great potential to produce value-added products from plastic waste. Electrocatalytic plastic upcycling, a form of heterogeneous catalysis, has distinct advantages, such as high durability, tunable production, simple separation, etc. However, a major drawback of the electrocatalytic pathway is the inertness of plastics, arising from their chemically robust backbones or hydrophobic surface, which leads to minimal participation in redox reactions on the electrode surface. Despite the inert property of the plastics, many efforts have been made to develop electrocatalytic pathways that successfully engage plastics in reactions to produce valuable products. Recently, the photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) approach has been applied to plastic upcycling. PEC reaction, a hybrid of electrocatalytic and photocatalytic reactions, harnesses light energy to drive electrocatalytic reactions. PEC plastic upcycling is an ultimately sustainable technique, as it does not consume fossil fuels and instead utilizes renewable energy to convert waste into valuable products. As the development of electrocatalytic and PEC plastic upcycling is gradually growing and their advancements have yet to be summarized, this review paper aims to introduce and comprehensively discuss recent progress in electrocatalytic plastic upcycling as well as PEC application and present new research directions for more economically plausible methods. 2 Fundamentals of plastic upcycling reaction mechanism 2.1 Electrocatalytic plastic upcycling reaction An electrocatalytic reaction involves a chemical process driven by electrical energy, typically occurring within an electrocatalytic cell consisting of two connected electrodes immersed in the electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). These electrodes, called anode and cathode, facilitate oxidation and reduction reactions, respectively, while an electrolyte transports charges via ions. Owing to its versatility, electrochemistry has become a mature and widely used technique in various applications, such as electroplatings, batteries, fuel cells, and water treatments [25–27]. The advantage of electrocatalytic cells lies in their ability to produce specific products through spatially distinct reduction and oxidation pathways, with a membrane separating the cathode and anode (Fig. 2b). This separation allows the creation of reductive and oxidative products separately, and the chemical reaction can be easily manipulated by adjusting voltage or current. Leveraging these advantages, electrocatalytic plastic upcycling becomes an efficient strategy, enabling the reduction or oxidation of polymers along specific pathways to yield valuable hydrocarbons. A crucial aspect of electrocatalytic plastic upcycling reactions is charge transfer which oxidizes or reduces the plastic materials. The charge transfer can happen directly at the electrode surface or indirectly via charge carrier mediators such as radicals. Since the plastics are generally bulky and hydrophobic, conventional electrocatalytic cells cannot simply oxidize or reduce plastics (Fig. 2b). This limitation significantly hinders the application of electrocatalytic cells in plastic treatment. Therefore, electrocatalytic cells are required to overcome this challenge via various strategies, and these will be detailed in subsequent chapters. Table 2 shows a summary of recently reported studies on plastic upcycling by electrocatalytic pathway. The first approach is to directly oxidize or reduce polymers or pre-treated polymers through anodic oxidation or cathodic reduction reactions, mostly in aqueous electrolytes (Fig. 2c). Given that most polymers are not inherently soluble in aqueous solutions, some can be made compatible through pre-treatment processes [28]. For instance, an alkaline solution hydrolyzes poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) into ethylene glycol (EG) and terephthalate, where the EG can participate in electrocatalytic reactions. This approach is effective because pre-treatment can hydrolyze the polymers that contain a number of carboxyl or hydroxyl groups in a molecule, making them soluble in aqueous electrolytes [29–33]. However, most polymers do not easily hydrolyze and dissolve in aqueous solution, limiting the applicability of aqueous electrocatalytic routes. To address this issue, some electrocatalytic plastic upcycling processes employ organic electrolytes like acetonitrile or tetrahydrofuran (THF). However, these organic electrolytes may suffer from reduced Faradaic efficiency (FE) [34,35]. The other approach for electrocatalytic plastic upcycling involves generating highly reactive free radical species, such as OH• and O2 •−, which can react with various polymers (Fig. 2c) [36–39]. For instance, some of the oxygen radical species are produced at the anode under elevated potentials, such as OH• from OH− at 1.89 V vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) and OH• from H2O at 2.72 V vs. NHE [40], while some of them are produced at the cathode, such as O2 •− at −0.33 V vs. NHE. The range of radicals produced in an electrocatalytic cell is not limited to oxygen species but can also extend to carbon or chlorine radicals present in the polymer structure [35]. Meanwhile, these radicals, while very reactive, are challenging to control and have very short lifetimes, such as 10−9 s for OH• [41]. Most radicals are lost before they can react with the polymer, so the selectivity and productivity of radical-assisted plastic upcycling tend to be lower compared to direct charge transfer reactions. Nevertheless, if the as-produced radicals can travel through the electrolyte for a sufficient duration, they can be suitable for a wide range of polymers, including those that do not readily dissolve in aqueous electrolytes. Therefore, in this review, we introduce the electrocatalytic upcycling of PET, poly(styrene) (PS), polyolefins, poly(ethylene furanoate) (PEF), poly(butylene terephthalate) (PBT), and poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC). Briefly, PET, PEF, and PBT are pre-treated to hydrolysate and upcycled to formic acid (FA) or succinic acid. PS is directly oxidized to dearomatized PS or oxidized bibenzyl in organic electrolyte. Polyolefins are converted into various depolymerized products by forming radicals, and lastly, PVC is upcycled to dechlorinated PVC. 2.2 Photoelectrocatalytic plastic upcycling reaction A PEC reaction represents an electrocatalytic process driven by either electrical or solar energy [42–46]. The PEC cell comprises two electrodes, with at least one of them being a photoelectrode, and an electrolyte, which is typically the same as a conventional electrocatalytic cell (Fig. 3 a). Fig. 3(a) represents the PEC cell composed of the photoanode which can absorb light. To absorb light, the photoanode is composed of semiconductor materials with specific band gaps. When the light is irradiated to the photoanode, electrons in the valence band get excited, rising to the conduction band. Meanwhile, a hole is generated in the vacated space within the valence band. These oppositely charged carriers travel the photoanode, with electrons moving toward the cathode and holes toward the surface of the anode. In this process, an applied electrical potential or spontaneously formed photovoltage acts as the driving force, propelling charge carriers to the electrode surface. Once at the electrode surface, these carriers are poised to transfer to the electrolyte, where catalytic reactions occur. Given that many semiconductor materials have poor surface catalytic activity, co-catalyst layers are often introduced to enhance the photoelectrode's performance [24,47]. While a PEC cell represents an ultimately clean and sustainable technique (Fig. 3b), it still requires further development, especially for plastic upcycling. For example, factors such as light absorption, charge separation, and catalytic reaction in PEC cells are intricately related to production rate and selectivity, making the design of suitable photoelectrode a complex challenge. Moreover, low efficiency with respect to the large band gap or fast charge recombination hinders its versatile applications. Table 3 shows a summary of recently reported studies on plastic upcycling by PEC pathway. Due to its numerous advantages, the PEC cell has been applied to various applications across many reactions, such as water splitting, CO2 reduction, wastewater treatment, etc. [48–54]. Notably, researchers have recently adapted PEC cells for plastic upcycling, with a particular focus on PET, as its pre-treatment facilitates direct charge transfer reactions. Unlike conventional electrocatalytic reactions, PEC reactions inherently involve the participation of electrons and holes from the conduction and valence bands of the semiconductor, respectively (Fig. 3c). It is known that when the energy level of the valence band maximum is more positive than the potential of the desired oxidation reaction, the generated hole can engage in the intended reaction. Similarly, when the energy level of conduction band minimum is more negative than desired reduction potential, the generated electron can participate into the desired reaction. Therefore, if the valence band position is sufficiently positive or its conduction band position is sufficiently negative, it can readily generate radical species such as OH• or O2 •− without the need for additional electric energy [55–58]. Furthermore, in other applications, PEC cells can employ organic electrolytes, which are beneficial for plastic upcycling reactions [59,60]. Consequently, it is true that opportunities indeed exist for developing PEC cells tailored to upcycle various types of polymers beyond PET. 3 Recent progress in electrocatalytic plastic upcycling 3.1 Poly(ethylene terephthalate) PET is a versatile and widely used thermoplastic polymer synthesized through the polymerization of terephthalic acid with EG. PET is used in manufacturing plastic bottles, containers, and packaging materials due to its transparency, light weight, and resistance to physical and chemical impacts. The unique molecular structure of PET provides it with good mechanical strength, thermal stability, and resistance to chemicals. Currently, PET is the most common plastic material for electrocatalytic upcycling because it can be hydrolyzed into EG and terephthalic acid in a heated KOH solution, while the hydrolysate is directly used as an electrolyte after the extraction of terephthalic acid. Therefore, the EG in the hydrolysate is a major reactant for the electrocatalytic upcycling process, where glycolic acid (GA), FA, or carbonates are the major products from EG oxidation reaction (EGOR). Moreover, extracted terephthalic acid itself is a valuable product from PET upcycling, as it is a raw material for various hydrocarbon products. Apart from the carbonate production, Zhao et al. reported FA production from PET upcycling [61]. They synthesized CuO nanowires grown on copper sheet and measured electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 4 a). They found that metal oxide has a major catalytic activity compared to corresponding metal hydroxide or oxyhydroxide by comparing electrocatalytic performances of Cu(OH)2 nanowires and CuO nanowire. Product analysis also demonstrated that the FA is a major product from the EGOR (Fig. 4b). A small amount of GA was observed during the long-term measurement, which implies that GA is a possible intermediate (Fig. 4c). Meanwhile, glyoxal, which is another possible intermediate, was not detected because glyoxal is easily transformed into GA by Cannizzaro reaction in alkaline solution, presented in Fig. 4(d). The density functional theory (DFT) calculation, as shown in Fig. 4(e), demonstrated that C–C bond cleavage of glyoxal intermediate on the CuO nanowire surface is the rate-determining step during the EGOR. It is worth noting that C–C bond cleavage has always suffered from inertness and weak electronic bias [62–65]. Therefore, they concluded that the glyoxal intermediate generation is the optimal reaction pathway to consequently produce FA. Mondal et al. synthesized cobalt-based one dimensional (1D) coordination polymer for electrocatalyst material [66]. They found an increase in carbonate ion concentration during electrocatalysis, attributed to the direct FA oxidation (Fig. 4f). Meanwhile, they demonstrated that oxalate (OA) formation pathway did not occur during the EGOR, confirmed by absence of OA in post-electrolysis sample measured by C13 nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (Fig. 4g). Also, they tested electrocatalytic oxidation of bis-hydroxyethyl terephthalate (BHET), an oligomer of PET. The results showed the presence of terephthalate, EG, FA, and carbonate after BHET oxidation. It is important that PET hydrolysate will not only contain terephthalate and EG but also have unhydrolyzed PET, such as oligomers, trigomers, etc. In addition, they found that the electrocatalytic BHET oxidation follows the first order with respect to the initial BHET concentration, suggesting that BHET oxidation also follows a similar rate-determining step and reaction pathway with EGOR. Chen et al. reported carbonate and terephthalate production from electrocatalytic PET upcycling [67]. They used Pd-decorated nickel foam (NF) as an electrode, synthesized through a displacement reaction. They found that increasing the concentration of KOH electrolyte from 1 to 10 M increases maximum current density and shifts EG oxidation peak potential more negatively, which implies a stronger alkaline environment facilitates more EGOR. Meanwhile, they observed decreasing current density to nearly zero during the chronoamperometry measurement at 0.7 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), which demonstrates that the EGOR is completed after certain hours. Since it was confirmed that no electrocatalytic reaction happens at 0.7 V vs. RHE without EG in the electrolyte, they concluded that zero current density implies the end of EGOR. During the chronoamperometry measurement, the production of glyoxal and the gradual conversion of EG to carbonate were observed. Based on these observations, Chen et al. proposed a mechanism involving the breaking of C–C bonds for the alkaline EGOR. The onset potential of electrocatalytic EGOR is generally more negative than water oxidation, making it beneficial for application in alkaline water electrolysis for hydrogen production. Indeed, bifunctional electrocatalysts that have good activity in both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) have been widely developed in alkaline water electrolysis [68–70]. Due to the high catalytic activity and low cost of first-row transition metal, bifunctional electrocatalyst has great advantages of lowering overall cost as well as reducing the complexity of electrolyzer. Taking advantage of both EGOR and bifunctional catalysts, some researchers reported bifunctional EGOR catalyst for PET upcycling. To ensure good HER activity of the bifunctional electrocatalyst, transition metal phosphide or nitride are used as catalytic materials [70,71]. Chen et al. used ultra-thin CoNi0.2P nanosheets attached to NF as electrodes for both EGOR and HER [72]. Note that transition metal phosphides are good alkaline HER catalyst materials due to the high electronegativities of phosphorous atoms, turning in the adsorption of more protons and reducing the HER overpotential [70]. They found a surface reconstruction of the catalyst surface into MO x (OH) y or MOOH after the EGOR, which are known as genuine active sites for transition metal compound catalysts (Fig. 5 a). Their catalyst showed outstanding performance, including 92% FE of EGOR at 1.3 V vs. RHE and 43 mV of overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 of current density. By combining anodic EGOR and cathodic HER with their catalysts, they achieved full cell operation with 1.24 V to reach 50 mA cm−2 with 0.3 g L−1 EG containing electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 5(b and c). A similar concept was studied by Zhu et al., where they synthesized an ordered macroporous superstructure catalyst composed of nickel and cobalt phosphide materials and used it as a bifunctional HER and EGOR electrocatalyst [73]. The catalyst has numerous ordered macropores as well as built-in mesopores, shown in Fig. 5(d), so it has either a large surface area or fast mass transfer through the pores. Their catalyst achieved 119 mV of HER overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 of current density and 1.30 V vs. RHE of potential at 10 mA cm−2 of current density for EGOR. After the EGOR, they observed surface reconstruction of their catalyst to nanosheet structure while the composition of the catalyst surface was tuned to Ni-CoOOH, which would be more thermodynamically favorable against EGOR (Fig. 5e–g). By combining two half-reactions into a full cell configuration, as illustrated in Fig. 5(h), the catalyst achieved 1.52 V to reach 10 mA cm−2 of current density using EG-containing electrolyte with respect to nearly 100% FE of H2 production as well as 93.2% FE of FA production (Fig. 5i and j). In addition, 1.57 V was required for a realistic 10 mA cm−2 of current density when they used PET hydrolysate as an electrolyte. Li et al. also reported a bifunctional electrocatalyst consisting of cobalt-modified nickel phosphide nanosheets on NF (Co-Ni2P/NF) for HER and PET upcycling [74]. Among the tested catalysts, Co0.6-Ni2P/NF demonstrated the most efficient HER activity, requiring only a 69 mV overpotential to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6 a). Additionally, as shown in Fig. 6(b), Co0.6-Ni2P/NF nanosheets exhibited the highest current density for the OER at the same voltage in a 1 M NaOH solution. Moreover, these nanosheets demanded a lower voltage for the electrooxidation of PET hydrolysate (Fig. 6c). Notably, this catalyst showed remarkable performance in alkaline conditions for electrooxidation of PET hydrolysate, reaching a current density of 50 mA cm−2 at a mere potential of 1.32 V. The primary product was FA, with a maximum FE of approximately 85% at 1.5 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6d). Through energy calculations, they determined that the C–C bond cleavage is the crucial and energy-limiting step for electrooxidation of EG on both pristine and cobalt-doped Ni2P surfaces. The incorporation of cobalt appears to enhance the reaction process and reduce energy consumption. A two-electrode electrolyzer employing Co-Ni2P/NF as the bifunctional electrocatalyst accomplished a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low voltage of 1.43 V, allowing simultaneous PET electroreforming and eco-friendly H2 generation, as presented in Fig. 6(e). Utilizing a flow-type cell for electrocatalytic plastic upcycling offers several benefits that enhance the efficiency and feasibility of the process. The flow cell configuration allows continuous and controlled electrolyte flow, maintaining consistent reactant concentrations and minimizing mass transport limitations [75,76]. This is particularly advantageous for electrocatalytic reactions involving complex polymeric materials like plastics, as it ensures uniform reaction conditions and maximizes contact between the catalyst and plastic feedstock. Duan et al. tested PET upcycling flow cells composed of zero gap membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) to overcome ohmic resistance which causes huge energy loss at high current density [77]. First, they found that stoichiometry of CoNi0.25P/NF showed the best HER and EGOR performance. Then, a zero-gap MEA flow reactor was designed for converting EG into FA paired with H2 production using CoNi0.25P/NF as both the cathodic and anodic catalysts (Fig. 7 a). As shown in Fig. 7(b), it reached a significantly higher current density (500 mA cm−2) at a low cell voltage (1.8 V), representing one of the most advantageous systems. In addition, the near-parallel polarization curves are presented for water splitting and EG electrolysis, showing a ∼189 mV decrease of cell voltage for reaching the same current density in the presence of EG in the analyte, which in turn increases the cathodic energy efficiency. Compared with common H-cell or single cell for anodic FA production from alcohols, the MEA reactor reached a significantly higher current density (500 mA cm−2) at a low cell voltage (<1.8 V) (Fig. 7c). Moreover, the EGOR at a constant current density of 300 and 500 mA cm−2 in MEA give FA productivity of 3.6 and 5.1 mmol cm−2 h−1, respectively, with good FE (>80%), again highlighting its advantageous nature (Fig. 7d). Further development was done by Duan et al. where they reported Au/Ni(OH)2 electrocatalyst that achieved high selectivity and current density for PET upcycling at moderate potentials [78]. Note that noble metal catalysts (such as Au, Pt, and Pd) have demonstrated considerable success in generating products that retain C–C bonds during the electrooxidation of alcohols at moderate potentials [79–81]. However, their performance often suffers from reduced FE at higher current densities, which deviates from practical expectations. Using their Au/Ni(OH)2 catalyst for EGOR, the primary outcome is GA with a production rate of 2.24 mmol cm−2 h−1 and a selectivity of 91% at 1.15 V vs. RHE, which is significantly improved compared to single Au catalysts (Fig. 7e). They found that the transformation of EG into GA on Au/Ni(OH)2 involves an initial electrooxidation of EG into glycolaldehyde (GD) through a nucleophilic dehydrogenation reaction, followed by conversion of GD to an enol form in the presence of a base, and another nucleophilic dehydrogenation step resulting in GA. Both experimental and theoretical findings indicate that molecules containing adjacent OH groups exhibit a lower pKa value, rendering them more prone to forming alkoxides under the reaction conditions, thereby enhancing their reactivity. Furthermore, as presented in Fig. 7(f and g), molecules in alkoxide forms accumulate at the Au/Ni(OH)2 interface due to interactions with both Au and Ni(OH)2. The presence of adjacent OH groups in alcohol facilitates heightened reactivity for C–H bond dehydrogenation due to the ease of alkoxide formation under the reaction conditions. The alkoxy group within alkoxides can also bind to Au through σ interactions. To gauge catalytic performance in a more practical setting, they constructed a custom membrane-free flow electrolyzer, as shown in Fig. 7(h). The stacked electrolyzer yielded an absolute current of ∼4.7 A at 1.4 V, resulting in a GA production rate of 471.2 mmol over 12.8 h (equivalent to 36.8 mmol h−1), with a selectivity of 94% and a FE of 96% for GA. Understanding reaction mechanisms is crucial as it provides essential insights into how chemical reactions occur at the molecular level, offering a deeper comprehension of fundamental processes in chemistry and enabling the development of more efficient and selective reactions [82,83]. Moreover, mechanistic understanding allows predicting reaction outcomes, designing optimized catalysts, and troubleshooting reactions that have gone awry. Chen et al. discovered the reaction mechanism of PET EGOR by using CuCo2O4 catalyst. They first compared EGOR performance of catalysts composed of similar elements such as CuCo precursor, CuO, Co3O4, and CuCo2O4 grown on NF substrate. It was found that CuCO2O4 has either the lowest overpotential or the smallest charge transfer resistance to EGOR. To understand the EGOR mechanism, the dynamic conversion of EG was monitored using NMR spectra and in-situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy [84]. The findings indicated the initial oxidation of EG into GD, followed by the rapid oxidation of GD into glyoxal and GA. Additionally, computational analyses demonstrated that CuCo2O4 possesses a d band center with less negative charge compared to Co3O4 and CuO, creating more unoccupied antibonding states facilitating the adsorption and activation of reactive species. Furthermore, the most minimal disparity in binding energy between EG and OH was observed on CuCo2O4, implying the significance of this energy difference in the EGOR process. The EGOR reaction encompasses various intermediates, including *EG, *GD, *Glyoxal, *GA, and *FA. They suggested that *Glyoxal emerges as the primary intermediate due to its more favorable energetic properties, aligning with the experimental finding that *Glyoxal is central to the EGOR mechanism. A different aspect was proposed by Chen and coworkers [85]. In order to explore the active components engaged in EGOR on Co-Ni3N/CC, researchers utilized in-situ Raman spectroscopy. It was revealed that the surface Ni(OH)2 transformed initially into NiOOH, which then efficiently oxidizes EG through quick regeneration of lower-valence Ni species (Fig. 8 a and b). The transformation of NiOOH was monitored by maintaining a potential of 1.34 V in an alkaline solution, as shown in Fig. 8(c), highlighting the role of NiOOH as the primary active center for the EGOR acting as a chemical oxidant. In addition, in-situ FTIR spectra captured under varied potentials showed distinct absorption bands at 1354 and 1388 cm−1, which were attributed to the symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate O–C–O (Fig. 8d). This suggested a sequential oxidation pathway as presented in Fig. 8(e), wherein EG is transformed into GD. This is followed by the formation of formaldehyde and FA, which subsequently undergoes a Cannizzaro reaction, resulting in the production of methanol and FA, with FA being the final product. The enhanced reactivity of heterostructured CoNi3N/CC catalyst was further expounded upon using DFT calculations (Fig. 8f and g), revealing beneficial charge exchange due to Co doping that facilitates the creation of catalytically active sites for both HER and EGOR. Furthermore, Gibbs free-energy diagrams unveiled that Co-Ni3N exhibits the lowest energy barrier for EGOR to FA, which involves an exothermic process encompassing the conversion of *CH3OH intermediate to FA and its subsequent surface desorption. 3.2 Poly(styrene) PS is a widely used synthetic polymer characterized by its lightweight, rigid, and versatile properties. It belongs to the family of thermoplastic polymers and is derived from styrene monomers through polymerization. PS is commonly found in various forms, including solid plastic items like disposable utensils, packaging materials, and foam products such as insulation, cups, and food containers. Its affordability, ease of manufacturing, and insulating properties have made it a popular choice in various industries. However, the resistance of the PS to degradation and its persistence in the environment have raised concerns about its environmental impact. PS is not easily biodegradable and can persist in the environment for centuries, contributing to plastic pollution. To address these issues, some researchers developed an electrocatalytic PS upcycling technique. Sarlah et al. reported electrocatalytic dearomatization of PS without chain degradation [34]. Dearomatization is a crucial part of synthetic chemistry, as it transforms arenes into products with greater utility and value. Electrocatalytic dearomatizations are a promising method for functionalizing aromatic polymers, providing novel materials that are inaccessible by any other means. As one of the typical aromatic polymers, PS was dearomatized using an electrocatalytic cell, as briefly illustrated in Fig. 9 (a). Different from PET upcycling, THF was used as an organic electrolyte in order to dissolve PS. A series of monodisperse PS samples, with molecular weights ranging from 4.0 × 103 to 1.8 × 106 Da, were subjected to identical electroreduction conditions, applying 1F mol−1. The results shown in Fig. 9(b) indicated a clear exponential decay, demonstrating that diffusion to the electrode is rate-limiting. They also investigated the scope of this electroreduction by applying optimized conditions to a variety of commercially available aromatic polymers, as summarized in Fig. 9(c). They found that the process could be extended to commercial PS-based copolymers containing different functionalities, but their limited solubility in THF resulted in suspensions and consequently eroded conversions. Activating inert sp 3-sp 3 carbon–carbon (C–C) bonds remains a major bottleneck in the chemical upcycling of plastic waste. Román-Leshkov et al. developed an electrocatalytic method to activate inert C–C bonds at room temperature and ambient pressure [35]. They showed that the N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI)/phthalimide-N-oxyl (PINO) redox couple functions as a mediator that initiates hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) reactions with benzylic C–H (Fig. 10 a and b). The resulting carbon radical is readily captured by molecular oxygen to afford a peroxide radical that decomposes into oxygenated products, as illustrated in Fig. 10(c). The mediated oxidation approach cleaved C–C bonds of oligomeric styrene (M n = 510 Da). As a proof-of-concept, they employed NHPI to mediate the oxidative depolymerization of PS (10,000 Da) and achieved a yield of monomers and dimers of 12% (Fig. 10d). The NHPI-mediated oxidation strategy demonstrates the potential of electrocatalysis in activating inert chemical bonds under mild conditions. Given the wide variety of redox mediators, this study opens the door to employing renewable electricity and targeted redox mediators to catalyze challenging chemical transformations. 3.3 Polyolefins Polyolefins, a class of versatile polymers, are distinguished by their unique molecular composition comprising carbon and hydrogen atoms. These polymers are synthesized from monomers like ethylene and propylene, giving them exceptional properties that have earned them a pivotal role in numerous industries. Their inherent advantages, such as relatively low density, lightweight character, remarkable durability, and robust chemical resistance, have positioned polyolefins as essential materials across a diverse range of applications. In the manufacturing sector, their malleability allows for intricate designs in plastic products, while their mechanical strength ensures the longevity of automotive components. The inherent chemical stability of polyolefins also makes them suitable for various applications requiring chemical resistance. Botte et al. introduced a novel technique for modifying low-density poly(ethylene) (LDPE) surfaces through electrochemistry in a water-based environment at room temperature and normal pressure [86]. As summarized in Fig. 11 (a), the procedure involves placing LDPE particles between two identical metal electrodes (copper, nickel, or stainless steel) that are in contact with corresponding metal ions dissolved in an electrolyte (Cu2+, Ni2+, or Fe2+/Fe3+). By altering the cell potential from 1 V to −1 V, the researchers observed that the LDPE surface underwent oxidation when exposed to copper electrodes/Cu2+ and nickel electrodes/Ni2+. This oxidation process led to the identification of C–O and C=O bonds on the LDPE surface (Fig. 11b). The most significant reaction occurred when LDPE underwent electrolysis with copper, leading to the emergence of new vibrational bands around 1150 and 1230 cm−1 in FTIR measurement. These bands were associated with C–O bonds in ether and ester groups (Fig. 11c). Electrolyzing LDPE with nickel caused the peak at 1080 cm−1 (associated with alcoholic/peroxide groups) to broaden. Notably, only the LDPE sample treated with copper exhibited a peak at 1735 cm−1, as shown in Fig. 11(d), indicating the presence of C=O bonds. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analyses were conducted to identify fatty acids and hydrocarbons. Intriguingly, high-quality dodecanoic acid was detected in LDPE samples treated with nickel and copper, providing clear evidence of chain scission (Fig. 11e). Furthermore, the detection of copper and nickel nanoparticles in the electrolyzed LDPE suggested that interactions between ions and polymer particles played a role in the electrooxidation mechanisms at cell potentials below the threshold for OER. Brantley et al. reported the electrocatalytic modification of soft polymer backbones, as briefly shown in Fig. 12 (a) [87]. In their experiment, dichloromethane (DCM) solution with supporting electrolyte 0.2 M N(Bu)4BF4 was used as an electrolyte to participate polymers into the electrocatalytic reaction. Also, the graphite/zinc (anode/cathode) combination was used rather than the RVC/Pt (anode/cathode) combination since they are low cost, easily cleaned for multiple uses, and provide good control over degradation reactions. They applied a constant potential to observe the oxidation of poly(norbornene) over various durations. Size exclusion chromatography (SEC) analysis of the resultant material showed a notable decrease in the calculated number average molecular weight (ΔMn = −207 kDa) after 16 h of electrocatalytic reaction (Fig. 12b). Extending the reaction time to 63 h continuously reduced the size of poly(norbornene) to 805 kDa. Moreover, plotting Mn against electrolysis time unveiled a consistent drop in molecular weight, indicating that chain scission occurred randomly along the polymer backbone. They then proposed that introducing a HAT reagent could suppress the formation of radical cations generated during anodic processes, consequently impeding chain scission. As expected, the inclusion of surplus 9,10-dihydroanthracene significantly decelerated the rate of polymer degradation. Integrating chemical modification with degradation also presented the prospect of yielding novel products with inherent value. Consequently, as presented in Fig. 12(c), poly(norbornene) (0.04 M in dichloromethane) was subjected to initial electrolysis in an undivided cell (E cell = 3.2 V) alongside MnBr2 (20 mol%) and trimethylsilyl azide (TMS-N3, 7.0 equiv). Analysis of azidated poly(norbornene) through FTIR indicated a new vibration corresponding to azidation (at approximately 2099 cm−1; ΔMn = −773 kDa). Their findings concluded that the single-electron oxidation of the olefin at the anode initially generates a radical cation within the polymer, which then undergoes β-scission. Various pathways, such as HAT, radical recombination, or nucleophilic trapping, can lead to the termination of the resulting radical and cationic chain ends. 3.4 Other polymers In spite of the limited number of plastic waste upcycling reported so far, valuable products have been produced through the electrocatalytic upcycling of certain engineering plastics. The chemical structure of PEF is similar to that of PET, where furanoate alters terephthalate. Therefore, PEF can also be hydrolyzed under alkaline solution to produce furan dicarboxylic acid and EG and its upcycling method is similar to PET. Zhao et al. showed that earth-abundant cobalt-based oxides can be used as electrocatalysts for the electrocatalytic oxidation of EG to produce FA and H2 at a constant potential of 1.40 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode [88]. They found that the oxidation of the PEF hydrolysate is kinetically more favorable than water oxidation, while the NiCo2O4 catalyst exhibits superior catalytic activity among the MCo2O4 catalysts. Also, they observed that GA appears to be more of a byproduct than a critical intermediate in the electrocatalytic oxidation of EG on the NiCo2O4 catalyst, as evidenced by the absence of OA in the reaction product. PBT is a thermoplastic material used in engineering, much like PEG and PEF. It boasts outstanding properties and is created through the polymerization of terephthalic acid and 1,4-butanediol (BDO) monomers. Like PET and PEF, PBT can be hydrolyzed in alkaline solution, breaking down into BDO and terephthalate. Thus, PBT is mostly upcycled by direct electrocatalytic oxidation of BDO. A study conducted by Chen et al. showed an electrocatalytic method for upcycling PBT using electro-activated NF [89]. During this process, the oxidation of BDO led to the production of valuable succinate. In-situ Raman spectroscopy results revealed that NiOOH acted as a chemical oxidant in the oxidation of BDO and reverted to low-valence Ni species after the reaction, explaining its catalytic activity onset before the OER initiated by higher-valence Ni4+ species (Fig. 13 a–c). Interestingly, they found that the presence of BDO hindered the appearance of signals related to Ni–O vibrations until the applied potential reached 1.70 V, signifying the reduction of Ni3+ in NiOOH and a slower formation of NiOOH. They carried out in-situ FTIR spectra at varying potentials to gain further insights into the reaction mechanism and identify reaction intermediates during the 1,4-butanediol oxidation reaction (BOR) process. Notably, absorption bands at 1564 and 2658 cm−1 appeared as the potential increases to 1.32 V, corresponding to the asymmetric O–CO stretching of COO− and the O–H stretching vibration of COOH, respectively (Fig. 13d). These changes indicated the formation of succinic acid. Moreover, a peak at 1720 cm−1 suggested the generation of aldehyde intermediates containing carbonyl groups, such as 4-hydroxybutanal and succinaldehyde. As presented in Fig. 13(e), DFT calculations showed that the O–H bond cleavage of BDO to form OH(CH2)3-HCO* is an endothermic process with a high ΔG value of 1.45 eV, making it the rate-determining step for BOR. Subsequently, the cleavage of O–H or C–H bonds to create OH(CH2)3-COOH* (ΔG = 0.24 eV) is expected to occur on NiOOH. Finally, the oxidation of OH(CH2)3-COOH* intermediate results in the production of the end product, succinic acid, in an exothermic process. PVC is known to pose environmental health risks and presents challenges in recycling due to its plasticizing additives and resulting byproducts. Conventional recycling methods such as melt-processing or pyrolysis prove ineffective even without plasticizing agents, primarily because of the rapid release of hydrochloric acid and other volatile compounds during heat treatment. McNell et al. detailed a method for upcycling PVC that involves chloroarenes production through electro(de)chlorination facilitated by plasticizer mediation [90]. In their research, the authors investigated the possibility of generating HCl on demand from discarded PVC and repurposing it for the chlorination of organic molecules. This innovative approach harnessed the substantial quantity of functional groups present in waste PVC. Through a plasticizer-mediated electro(de)chlorination process, organic molecules were chlorinated using PVC. To explain briefly, PVC underwent dechlorination at the cathode, yielding HCl, while the anode-induced chlorination of arenes involving PVC plasticizer produced chloroarenes and hydrogen gas. It was observed that PVC itself lacked redox activity within the solvent parameters, but di-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) (a plasticizer) underwent two consecutive reductions with a discernible redox behavior. Regardless of the mechanism by which electrons were introduced to PVC, the reduction process likely involved the detachment of chloride anions (Cl−) from PVC through a concerted electron-transfer-bond-breaking mechanism, akin to the process proposed for small-molecule alkyl halides. The resultant macroradical consisting of carbon could be exceptionally reactive and might follow multiple reaction pathways. Ultimately, released Cl− ions participated in the chlorination of arene substrates at the anode, with intermediates like Cl2 or hypochlorite possibly being engaged in the oxidative chlorination, potentially transforming Cl− into a chlorine radical or participating in the arene chlorination process. 4 Recent progress in photoelectrocatalytic plastic upcycling 4.1 Photoelectrode development for plastic upcycling The PEC plastic upcycling technique offers a promising and innovative solution to the pressing issue of plastic waste. Unlike traditional recycling methods that often result in downcycling or energy-intensive processes, this approach leverages the power of sunlight and specialized photoactive materials to break down plastic waste into valuable chemicals efficiently. One of its primary advantages compared to electrocatalytic reactions is its energy-saving feature, which harvests solar energy and converts it into chemicals, reducing the energy cost of the overall plastic upcycling process. Yi et al. developed an artificial leaf capable of reforming PET with high selectivity, as well as generating hydrogen, using solar energy [91]. The process involved the oxidation of EG at nanoNi-Pop(CV) and nanoNi(CV) electrodes, which entails the electrocatalytic formation of active NiOOH species followed by a reaction between EG and NiOOH. As shown in Fig. 14 (a), the significantly pronounced decrement in the cathodic current of the r1 peak in the presence of EG suggests that NiOOH would be the active species responsible for electrocatalysis. NanoNi-Pop(CV) exhibited higher catalytic current responses to EG than nanoNi(CV), which could be attributed to the higher amount of active –NiOOH sites available for electrocatalytic EGOR (Fig. 14b). They attempted the application of nanoNi-Pop(CV) to the PEC reforming of PET. NanoNi-Pop(CV) was loaded onto the surface of nanoTiO2 photoanode as a co-catalyst, and the photocurrent was measured under simulated light (Fig. 14c–h). As shown in Fig. 14(i and j), they found that higher current density from nanoNi-Pop(CV) loaded nanoTiO2 compared to bare nanoTiO2 originated from the reduced interfacial charge transfer resistance, which was attributed to the improved kinetics against EGOR. Zhao et al. also reported that a visible light active Fe2O3/Ni(OH) x photoelectrode can selectively oxidize waste PET plastic to produce FA with high efficiency and selectivity (Fig. 15 a) [92]. FA, OA, and a trace amount of GA were detected as a product from PEC EGOR, as shown in Fig. 15(b). Based on their result, they proposed a Ni2+/Ni3+ redox couple-mediated working mechanism for the selective oxidation of the PET hydrolysate. The conventional PEC water splitting process with Ni(OH) x as the electrocatalyst continuously oxidizes the Ni2+ species into the Ni3+ or higher-valence species to provide sufficient active sites for water oxidation. However, the Ni(OH) x layer could effectively modulate the oxidation ability of the photogenerated holes to achieve the highly selective oxidation of EG to FA. Additionally, they enhanced the Fe2O3/Ni(OH) x photoelectrode by introducing a TiO x interlayer between the Fe2O3 and the Ni(OH) x layers (Fig. 15c) [93]. This interfacial modification with the TiO x interlayer boosted the PEC activity by extending the lifespan of photogenerated holes and kept the high selectivity for FA over a long-term test, ensuring efficient charge carrier transport between the Fe2O3 and the Ni(OH) x layers (Fig. 15d and e). Similarly, Chu and coworkers developed an α-Fe2O3 photoelectrode modified with Ni-Pi for PEC PET upcycling [94]. As shown in Fig. 15(f), Ni-Pi/α-Fe2O3 displayed the best FA FE, reaching 87%, and the lowest GA FE, which was only 11%. In contrast, the bare α-Fe2O3, CoOOH/α-Fe2O3, CoPi/α-Fe2O3, and NiOOH/α-Fe2O3 samples exhibited poor FA FE, all falling below 70%. Notably, Ni exhibited favorable catalytic performance in breaking C–C bonds to form FA in comparison to the other samples, while the presence of Pi further improved the catalytic selectivity of NiOOH. They found that the optimal condition for FA generation was a Ni-Pi loading of 1 mM, striking a balance between providing enough catalytic sites and ensuring effective light absorption. To gain insight into the outstanding performance of Ni-Pi/α-Fe2O3 at the atomic level, spin-polarized DFT calculations were conducted. The results presented in Fig. 15(g and h) revealed that the combined effect of the Ni-Pi co-catalyst, as opposed to NiOOH alone, enhanced the adsorption of HOCH2CH2OH and facilitated the rapid removal of HCOOH generated during the oxidation reaction from the surface of the catalyst. 4.2 Application to full cell configuration By developing PET upcycling, it is possible to reduce overpotential more effectively compared to the OER, which in turn enhances the overall efficiency, particularly in full cell configurations. This reduction in overpotential is crucial for solar-driven full cells, where the cell potential is limited by the photovoltage. Zhao et al. further refined their CuO nanowire catalyst [61], integrating it as an anode in a photovoltaic electrochemical flow reactor (PV-EFR) to demonstrate the feasibility of a light-driven and spontaneous plastic upcycling system [95]. First, they tested their catalyst in an electrochemical flow reactor (EFR) without photovoltaic cells. Operating in a two-electrode full cell mode, the EFR yielded a FA production of 16.1 mmol L−1 and a hydrogen production rate of 20.8 mol min−1, equating to a total electric-to-chemical efficiency of 96.6%. Moreover, during the 120-h of stability test, no evident degradation in activity as well as selectivity was observed, while continuously producing an FA concentration of 11.0 mmol L−1. They also proved that CuO nanowire catalyst is stable after the stability test by XPS spectra. After the evaluation of CuO nanowire catalyst, they applied photovoltaic panels to power the EFR. Through their optimizations in irradiated light intensity and electrolyte flow rate, their PV-EFR achieved a stable current density of 24 mA cm−2 and FA production of 13.8 mmol L−1 under light irradiation of AM 1.5G simulated 100 mW cm−2. More interestingly, they verified their PV-EFR system under natural solar irradiation. Despite the floating sunlight intensity between 50 and 75 mW cm−2 due to the local weather, they observed a stable generation of FA of 6.50 μmol min−1 during a 120-h test. Different from the above development of photoanode for plastic upcycling, Reisner et al. presented a novel PEC full cell for the purpose of solar-waste reforming [96]. Note that the full cell configuration is the ultimate structure of the PEC cell, which is driven by only solar energy [97–101]. They introduced a bimetallic Cu30Pd70 alloy micro-flower as a highly selective catalyst for the oxidation of waste materials. This catalyst was combined with lead-halide perovskite photocathodes, employing platinum (Pt) as a catalyst for the production of clean H2. These systems were evaluated in both “artificial leaf” and two-compartment configurations, as shown in Fig. 16 (a and b), to assess their performance in light-driven waste reforming without an external bias. Furthermore, the researchers tested various waste feedstocks, including glycerol, PET, and biomass-derived substrates. The results showed that solar-driven “artificial leaves” had the capability to selectively convert waste substrates into valuable industrial chemicals such as glyceric acid, GA, and gluconic acid while simultaneously generating clean H2 with high efficiency (Fig. 16c and d). These devices were reusable over four cycles of 1 h, maintaining a relatively consistent current density and steady H2 production, except for an initial issue with Pt poisoning. The Cu30Pd70|perovskite|Pt two-compartment system offered additional advantages compared to “artificial leaves”. Based on their results on measuring two-compartment configuration (Fig. 16e and f), it allowed for the utilization of a dark mixed-waste solution on the anodic side without blocking the light in the cathodic compartment, which is not possible in photocatalytic processes with homogenous or heterogeneous photocatalysts. This separation also enabled a better optimization and rational development of the individual redox catalysts, which is challenging with semiconductor powders. 4.3 Dual value-added chemicals production Reisner’s group further developed their bimetallic catalyst and applied it to simultaneous CO2 reduction and PET reforming systems [102]. Representatively, they fabricated a two-compartment system composed of Cu27Pd73 as an anode, perovskite as a light absorber in the photocathode, and three different CO2 reducing catalysts as co-catalysts in the photocathode. The three different CO2 reduction co-catalysts are alkyl-functionalized cobalt porphyrin (CoPL) molecular catalyst, copper-indium (Cu91In9) bimetallic alloy, and tungsten (W)-formate dehydrogenase from Desulfovibrio vulgaris Hildenborough (FDH) biological catalyst. Each of the three co-catalysts showed different productivity when they were used for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reactions; for instance, CoPL produces CO dominantly, Cu91In9 produces CO and H2 similarly, and FDH only produces FA. These trends remained consistent when the co-catalysts were applied to the photocathode and coupled to PET reforming. On the other hand, the anode catalyst material, Cu27Pd73, showed nearly 100% FE about GA formation regardless of co-catalyst materials in the photocathode, while GA yield was the highest when Cu91In9 was used as a co-catalyst in the photocathode. As Reisner’s group applied PET upcycling to PEC CO2 reduction reaction in order to realize dual production of value-added products at both anode and cathode, similar work has done by Kim et al. [103]. They presented a novel approach to biocatalytic artificial photosynthesis, utilizing solar energy to synthesize value-added chemicals from PET microplastics. A Zr-doped hematite photoanode extracts electrons from hydrolyzed PET solutions while producing FA and acetate, and the electrons are transferred to a carbon-based cathode to activate various redox enzymes such as unspecific peroxygenase and L-glutamate dehydrogenase. These enzymes facilitate a range of organic synthetic reactions, including oxyfunctionalization of C–H bonds, amination of C=O bonds, and asymmetric hydrogenation of C=C bonds. The efficiency of this method is demonstrated by its high total turnover numbers for enzymes, and the Zr:α-Fe2O3 photoanode shows improved charge-separation efficiencies, decreased charge-transfer resistance, and enhanced electron extraction capabilities, demonstrating that real-world microplastics can provide electron feedstocks to accelerate photobiosynthetic reactions with excellent total turnover numbers. 5 Conclusions and perspectives In this comprehensive review, we provide an extensive overview of research into plastic upcycling using electrocatalytic and PEC methods. Plastic upcycling includes various approaches, such as direct reuse of plastic materials, use as fuel for combustion, catalytic conversion into valuable chemicals, etc. Among these pathways, catalytic plastic upcycling stands out as a promising technology to address the current plastic waste crisis. Especially, electrocatalytic and PEC methods offer significant advantages in terms of energy efficiency and the ability to manipulate chemical reactions, and they have gained considerable attention in recent years. However, these techniques still require further development to truly benefit humanity. The primary challenge lies in initiating chemical reactions to disassemble or functionalize the inherently stable polymer structure of plastics. Despite these challenges, researchers are actively exploring innovative strategies to activate inert polymers, for instance, the pre-treatment of polymers, the use of organic electrolytes, or the formation of highly reactive radicals. It is notable that ruling a C–C bonding of the polymer is important because some polymers containing C–C bonding as a backbone require cleaving to become a monomer, while a C–C bonding in a monomer or a functional group of the polymer may be secured to become a specific product. The electrocatalytic cleavage of C–C bonds in organic molecules has gained widespread attention and appears applicable to plastic upcycling reactions [62,65,104,105]. Moreover, recent studies in electrocatalysis focus on manipulating reaction pathways on catalyst surfaces to produce specific products. For example, some reports apply TEMPO, a molecular catalyst for converting alcohols into aldehydes, in electrocatalytic and PEC reactions [106–109]. This application of catalysts can improve the diversity and efficiency of plastic upcycling reactions, resulting in increased economic benefits. In addition to focusing on enhancing the participation of plastics in electrocatalytic or PEC reactions, it is noteworthy that replacing one of the poor redox reactions in conventional electrocatalytic or PEC cells, such as water oxidation, with highly efficient plastic upcycling reactions will improve their efficiency in terms of energy cost as well as product value. Likewise, the experiences gained from developing electrocatalytic and PEC reactions, such as water splitting, hold promise for advancing plastic upcycling. These insights may lead to broader applications and new avenues for the development of plastic upcycling solutions. Sungsoon Kim received his Ph.D. in Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at Yonsei University, Republic of Korea, in 2023 under the supervision of Prof. Jong Hyeok Park. He is currently postdoctoral researcher in Prof. Xiaolin Zheng’s group at Stanford University. His research interests include the surface and interface engineering of nanomaterials for electrochemical and PEC cells. Dongjae Kong is a Ph.D. student at the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Stanford University. He received his B.S. and M.S. in Mechanical Engineering from Seoul National University in 2016 and 2018, respectively. Before joining Stanford University, he was a full-time lecturer at the Department of Aerospace Engineering, Republic of Korea Air Force Academy. His research interest now covers electrolysis, electrocatalysts, and nanomaterials for energy applications. Xiaolin Zheng is a Prof. in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Stanford University. She received her Ph.D. in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering from Princeton University in February 2006. Prior to joining Stanford in 2007, she conducted postdoctoral work in the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at Harvard University. She received the TR35 Award from the MIT Technology Review (2013) and the Presidential Early Career Award (PECASE) from the White House (2009). Her research focuses on water electrolysis, machine learning for material design, combustion of energetic materials, and silicon nanowires for energy and environmental applications. JongHyeok Park is a Prof. at the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at Yonsei University, Republic of Korea. He received his PhD in chemical engineering from KAIST, Republic of Korea, in August 2004. Then, he joined the University of Texas at Austin, as a postdoctoral researcher in 2004 (under Prof. Allen J. Bard). From March 2007 to February 2008, he worked at ETRI. He is an author and a co-author of more than 350 papers and 50 patents. His research focuses on PEC cells, secondary batteries, and perovskite solar cells.

coredata.dc:description: Plastic, renowned for its versatility, durability, and cost-effectiveness, is indispensable in modern society. Nevertheless, the annual production of nearly 400 million tons of plastic, coupled with a recycling rate of only 9%, has led to a monumental environmental crisis. Plastic recycling has emerged as a vital response to this crisis, offering sustainable solutions to mitigate its environmental impact. Among these recycling efforts, plastic upcycling has garnered attention, which elevates discarded plastics into higher-value products. Here, electrocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic treatments stand at the forefront of advanced plastic upcycling. Electrocatalytic or photoelectrocatalytic treatments involve chemical reactions that facilitate electron transfer through the electrode/electrolyte interface, driven by electrical or solar energy, respectively. These methods enable precise control of chemical reactions, harnessing potential, current density, or light to yield valuable chemical products. This review explores recent progress in plastic upcycling through electrocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic pathways, offering promising solutions to the plastic waste crisis and advancing sustainability in the plastics industry.
